thread.title: Eagles tackle breast cancer by tie-dyeing socks pink with community volunteers
thread.title_full: Eagles tackle breast cancer by tie-dyeing socks pink with community volunteers

author: Donald Hunt Tribune Staff Writer
title: Eagles tackle breast cancer by tie-dyeing socks pink with community volunteers
text:
Previous Next spt-notes100915 
From left, Eagles defensive tackle Bennie Logan, quarterback Mark Sanchez and tight end Trey Burton tie-dye socks pink for Breast Cancer Awareness Month. — Photo/The Philadelphia Eagles Posted: Friday, October 9, 2015 12:00 am Eagles tackle breast cancer by tie-dyeing socks pink with community volunteers   
Eagles tackle breast cancer by tie-dyeing socks pink with community volunteers, high school football players 
In an effort to help spread awareness and to honor lives that have been lost, the Philadelphia Eagles recently partnered with the Family Lives on Foundation to tie-dye socks pink for Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Eagles players, Family Lives On members who have been directly affected by breast cancer and South Philadelphia High School football players worked collaboratively on the project. The pink tie-dyed socks were been donated to South Philadelphia High School for their Breast Cancer Awareness game on Oct. 8. 
A 2015 Eagles Care partner, the Family Lives On Foundation of Exton, Pennsylvania, supports the lifelong emotional well-being of children whose mother or father has died. The Family Lives On Tradition Program supports parentally bereaved children and teens in continuing traditions they shared with their deceased parent. 
During the NFL season, Monday is typically reserved as a day off for the team. Many Eagles players, however, use this opportunity to enhance the quality of life for residents in the Delaware Valley through the Eagles Care Community Monday initiative. 
On Sunday, Oct. 11, the Eagles will host the New Orleans Saints at Lincoln Financial Field. The kickoff is set for 1 p.m. on FOX29. 
Delaware 87ers to hold open tryout in Philly on Oct. 11 
The Delaware 87ers will host a final open tryout before the upcoming 2015-16 NBA Development League basketball season on Sunday, Oct. 11. The last-chance tryout session will take place at Temple University’s Pearson McGonigle Hall, located at 1800 North Broad St. from 8:30 a.m. to noon. 
Players in attendance will be evaluated by Philadelphia 76ers and Delaware 87ers basketball operations staff. All players are competing for a chance to be invited to Sevens training camp in November. 
Those interested in participating must submit the official registration and release forms, as well as a $150 non-refundable entry fee to the Delaware 87ers. Forms and payment can be completed online at www.sevens.com/tryouts . 
Online registration closes at noon on Friday, Oct. 9. Late or day-of registration will cost $200 for all entries. All walk-up payments must be paid in cash, as no other forms of payment will be accepted at the door. 
Upon arrival, parking can be found at Liacouras Garage on 15th Street between Montgomery and Cecil B. Moore avenues. Daily parking rates for the garage are $17, and are not included in the 87ers open tryout fee. 
The Delaware 87ers of the National Basketball Association Development League (NBADL) were relocated to America’s first state in 2013 and named to commemorate the year in which Delaware ratified the U.S. Constitution, 1787. The Sevens are the NBADL affiliate of the NBA’s Philadelphia 76ers and are owned by the Sixers. The 87ers play at the University of Delaware’s Bob Carpenter Center in Newark, Delaware. 
SBN Sports Network Black College Football Poll 
Alcorn State is the No. 1 HBCU football team in the SBN Sports Network Black College Football Poll for this week. Here’s a complete list of the network’s top 10 poll: 
1. Alcorn State 
2. North Carolina A&T 
3. Southern
